reviewText:
Ok, I deserved this I suppose.

This is what I get for buying blind, trusting to Steams now seemingly non-existent quality thresholding and not waiting for reviews to be posted first.

School boy error on my behalf, won't be doing that again.

Anyway, my buyers remorse aside, this game is sub-freeware quality garbage. If you want a FNAF clone then there are plenty of better ones going for free on Gamejolt's website. Otherwise just buy the actual FNAF and reward the game creator for having the original concept in the first place.

Don't be a plank like me and pay for this poorly made, derivative garbage.

You have been warned !!

reviewText:
I've never played FNAF before, but I have seen enough videos to know that this game is a complete clone of it, maybe with a few slight changes, but nothing to class anything in it as 'original'. Far from it in fact.

I'm trying to think of some pro's and cons, but the only pros I can think of are that it is cheap (I got it for ¬£1.33), the actual animation of the 'Alien?' was pretty good.....I guess, annddd it ran smoothly on my piece of S*** Laptop! But I'm scraping from the bottom of the barrel here.

As far as cons go I'll just say:

- Unoriginal
- No settings option, so I couldn't change the resolution or anything (Unless somehow I missed it!)
- Not scary at all
- Some of the gameplay mechanics don't really make sense.
- Not entertaining
- Either the time goes too slow, or the power drains too quickly

I did a short let's play video of it if you fancy seeing a bit of gameplay.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=487896314

Yeah, I suck at reviews, but I think what I'm trying to say is: Just play FNAF and don't waste your time and money on this, unless you wanna laugh at it.

reviewText:
AN ABOMINATION - DO NOT BUY
A Five Nights at Freddy's clone, assuming the use of the word clone could be extended to describe a tapeworm's relation to a human: As in yes, they are technically both alive, are both from the animal kingdom, and share some basic DNA between them, but ultimately one is simply a parasite that tries to feed off the other.

So it is with this game. Devoid of anything new, lacking in artistry, backwards in content, singularly lacking in fun. An example of the worst in me too"-type game design.

My experience in this game is sadly documented in this video
date:
because I've made it my goal of covering all new horror games:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=490678359

This is the first time I've truly regretted that decision."
helpfulPercent: 36 of 41 people (88%) found this review helpful 9 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I'll start by saying its no sin for taking a leaf out of the popular FNAF series. A simple game built around, simple functions required to keep the numerous animatronics at bay. Of course the back story, and the ingame methods used can be anything but simple in the juggle to stay alive. Love them or hate them the FNAF series are the pinnacle in their genre.

So where does Naninights fit in? Well the entry is ¬£1.99. It covers the very basics of a point and click horror game. There is a threat, cameras and at least 3 ways to stop that threat. You would think that its all that is required to give Scott nightmares? Well no.. you see where Scott has mastered and understood what makes FNAF what it is. Maxim Moore clearly doesn't understand whats required or hasn't the ablitiy to put it in place.

For a start off, the game launches only in windowed mode. The night lasts forever more or less. Only one threat, which I'll add doesn't add any horror to the title. The bare min of rooms and cameras added, unclear instructions, poor translations (or getting Mary's sex wrong), Testube Mary disappears somewhere while still viewing the camera and just overall a game that feels dull and put together with little thought.

reviewText:
Alone in a lab you must survive the night as a young test subject roams the place hunting for you: sounds interesting? Well too bad Naninights is a terrible FNAF clone with no redeeming qualities whatsoever.

PROS:

-none

CONS:

-horrible graphics, it looks very low res and blurry

-you're stuck in windowed mode with a terrible Windows-style menu tab on top

-barebones soundtrack

-laughable sound effect

-the enemy is not menacing at all, in fact it looks and sounds silly and its jumpscare is cringeworthy

-broken gameplay punishes you if you play as you're supposed to, the third level also seems to be totally random in how and when you die

-little to no story

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=551030044

Naninights is a mess, there's no way around it. The graphics and sound are horribly bad and being forced to play in a small borderless window is something I honestly have no words for, just look at the image that goes with this review.

The gameplay is also terrible, you're supposed to be looking for the kid through cameras and use the according objects to make it go away, sadly it doesn't work. This is because the enemy will sometimes switch rooms in a matter of seconds leaving you with no time to react: this is made worse by the fact that certain things, like the mirror, are bugged and show the enemy even when it has already left.

I finally managed to beat the first two levels by simply doing nothing, waiting for the indicator that tells you Naninights is near to show up and quickly activating two defences while spamming the mirror up and down (cause keeping it up doesn't work, another bug). This dull exercise worked until I reached the third level where the mirror stopped working: it basically either didn't stop the kid or just showed its face making me lose tons of mind power: is this purposefully broken to make the game hard" or did they just not bother to test it? You decide.

Naninights is an embarassing "thing" and I can't help but think it's been cobbled together in a few minutes by people with no shame just to ride the FNAF hype train: it's not worth your time
recommended: just watch a video on Youtube."

reviewText:
How is this a point and click adventure, or even a horror game?

This is a more like a comedy spoof at best. The monster is 8 years old, and makes hilariously funny noises. Nothing is scary, and there's no adventure to point and click though. It's a terrible terrible attempt to capture what made Five Night's at Freddy's a hit.

Please avoid this, and the follow gameplay footage shows you everything you need to know about the game.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r1EKlFdmNPQ

reviewText:
Basic synopsis: This seriously needs QA.  It's not horrible, but in my opinion, it's nowhere near good.

I've beaten all phases, and have beaten all phases on Hard++ mode.  I still don't get it.

{ Gameplay }
- I beat the first two parts of the game by closing the gate and lighting the cube whenever I saw the warning graphic.  I ended each of these parts with just about 100% in each category.
- I beat the third part of the game by staring at him the ENTIRE NIGHT with the mirror with the gate open and the cube off.  Hard+ and Hard++ mode, you can do the same thing if you see him up close in the hallway.  None of this is explained.
- Hard++ mode seems really random, but after beating it, you just hear the alarm go off and you are taken back to the main menu.  Absolutely nothing special for winning this due to a bug in the .ini save file.  If you transfer the info written to the wrong file to the correct file, you see a new background image...but I have no clue what it means.

{ Presentation & Bugs }
- The game has tons of spelling and grammatical errors (see 'How to Play' for the ultimate example -- e.g. keep you Mind"
voteText: "for the rest levels").\n- There is a flicker on the home screen that makes it look like a graphical bug
helpfulPercent: even if it's not.\n- The "jumpscare" noise is more hilarious than anything else.  It sounds like a one-take random growl noise.\n- The "A.L.I.F.A." mask is never explained
votesHelpful: and the story is not drawn out to any satisfying level.\n- The font on the Hard+ and Hard++ menu is all messed up...way too big
votesTotal: and overlaps the text you need to see.\n- The About screen has a big blank text box...no content.  Just the author up top.  It's also a pop-up window
votesFunny: which isn't characteristic for any of the rest of the presentation.\n- Instructions in-game are also incorrect.  The cube won't stop "Naninight" unless he is in the "bedroom"/crib room...but there's really no advantage in looking at the "camera" or whatever until Hard++ mode
commentsCount: when the alert for Naninight is disabled.\n- The music also cuts out and never loops on the How to Play page
column16: which is very odd.  Loud with no resolution
column17: then nothing.\n- Volume is deafening on some of the piano riffs on side menus
column18: but gameplay isn't nearly as loud.\n- Hard+ mode is labeled as "Standard difficulty" under the text that says "Hard+"...\n- Beating Hard++ mode all the way through gets you NOTHING.  This is due to a save file error.  The main game saves to Enjoy (file)
column19: but the other modes save to Enjoy.ini.  The background is based on Enjoy
column20:
but it never gets the updated data to put the actual ending graphic.  You literally get nothing special due to that bug.
- Fun fact: You can hear the alarm noise and still die.

{ vs. FNAF }
- At least Naninights doesn't mess up your screen resolution by defaulting incorrectly in CTF application settings...but this is due to the restriction set in-game.  It's a simple fix for FNAF
column21: but it was never actually resolved properly.  However
column23: so you can't move the Naninights window.  Even more
column24: clicking on Fullscreen doesn't work at all in Naninights.\n- Music still plays when the window isn't in focus
column25: which is a good thing.  FNAF?  Change to another window and you don't get any audio.\n- Disabling Music doesn't Disable Music.\n- Story in Naninights isn't nearly as endearing as FNAF
column26: and story frankly isn't explained in any real depth in Naninights.  Why does lighting a cube stop a kid with a mask on from...growling in your face?  Does he kill you?  Does he just make you laugh and thus
column27: you lose since you can't laugh at your job?  It's never explained.  A.L.I.F.A. mask..what even?  Also -- what does "Naninight" mean
column28: and why is this kid nicknamed that?  Why does the kid wear the mask?"

reviewText:
We‚Äôre reaching that time of year where, once again, the ghosts, ghouls and vampires come out of the woodwork and begin to walk the streets in search of brains, blood and ungodly amounts of sweets. With Hallow‚Äôs Eve soon to be upon us all I was eager to find a suitably scary game in my Steam library, to get me in a spooky mood. It was slim pickings except the FEAR games, Five Nights at Freddy‚Äôs and a little-known game called ‚ÄúNaninights‚Äú. Having never played Naninights before, I loaded it up and boy was I terrified by what I saw.

For all intents and purposes, Naninights is Five Nights at Freddy‚Äôs. Well, it would be if Five Nights at Freddy‚Äôs was a complete piece of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing dog ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

Instead of Freddy and his band of animatronic bad guys, Naninights gives us some sort of failed infant experiment, wearing a gas mask. Spooky ‚Ä¶.(!)

The basic premise of the game is the same as Freddy: keep an eye on the other corridors and rooms in the building, and manage your energy reserves effectively so that you can make it through until morning. Failing to keep your eye on the titular ‚ÄúNananight‚Äù results in the usual jump-scare and the game spits you straight back on to the menu screen. Yet, even with the barest of feature sets, Naninights‚Äô developer still manages, somehow, to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• things up even further.

Graphically, the game looks beyond dated, sound effects are on an endless loop and there are zero options whatsoever ‚Äì not even for resolution. Naninights is the kind of game you‚Äôd expect a group of executives to greenlight at a business meeting, I imagine the meeting went something along the lines of:

Corporate guy:

‚ÄúI hear jump-scares are all the rage these days, can we make something quick to take advantage of that?‚Äù

Developer:

‚ÄúWe could, but Scott Cawthon has that market pretty much cornered. He‚Äôs published 8 Five Nights at Freddy‚Äôs games since Monday‚Äù

Corporate guy:

‚ÄúWell tough ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. The market wants jump-scares and we‚Äôre getting in on that action. Make me a clone of these Five Nights at Freddy‚Äôs games you mentioned. If you could, give it a really stupid name, try to make it look much worse, be really boring to play and be a generally ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• experience for everybody. Oh, and have it on Steam by the end of the day. Thanks!‚Äù

Developer:

‚ÄúUhh..‚Äù


Only, there was no corporate meeting. Naninights is the ‚Äòeffort‚Äô of a single developer; a cynical ploy to line their pockets and to dupe unsuspecting gamers out of their hard-earned cash. That‚Äôs the scariest part of all this.

I‚Äôm not offended by Naninight‚Äòs attempts to clone Freddy, rather I am offended by the sheer lack of effort put into it by its developer ‚Äì and that the people at Black Shell Media could publish this tripe with a straight face.

This game is a product of the ‚Äúme-too‚Äù generation, where no marketplace can be too overcrowded. It‚Äôs a quick cash-in farted out in a couple of days and then ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out on the Steam storefront. For the love of God, don‚Äôt buy it.



If you enjoyed my review, why not visit my website?
http://criticalindiegamer.com/2015/10/5-nights-of-development-if-that-naninights/

Is this an early access game, a flash game, or was it simply made to insult players' taste?
